conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their position and size depend on the position of the light source relative to the object, the distance between the light source and the object, and the angle at which light hits the object.
The light source is positioned such that it casts shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground, and the objects are positioned in a way that their shadows fall at specific points on the ground.
When the light source moves backward, it increases the distance between the light source and the objects, changing the angle at which the light hits the objects and causing the shadows to move.
Shadows will move in the direction opposite to the direction in which the light source moves; since the light source moves backward, shadows will move forward (toward the objects).
As the light source moves farther away from the objects, the shadows will generally become smaller because the light rays are more parallel, leading to smaller shadow projections.
Shadow A (Cake) moves forward towards the cake and becomes smaller in size.
Shadow B (Black Object) moves forward towards the black object and becomes smaller in size.
Shadow C (Sandals) moves forward towards the sandals and becomes smaller in size.
Shadow D (Metal Object) moves forward towards the metal object and becomes smaller in size.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, the shadows (A, B, C, and D) will move forward toward the objects and become smaller in size.
Final Answer: Shadows will move forward toward the objects and become smaller in size.
